questions.text: Total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of same reproductive age is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TFR (Total Fertility Rate)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group is referred to as the Total Fertility Rate (TFR).
  • • The following definitions are provided:
  • • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths) GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group
  • • TFR: Total number of children born to a woman
  • • GRR: Number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan
  • • NRR: Total number of girls born to a woman in her entire reproductive lifespan, minus mortality (taking into account their deaths)
  • • GFR: Number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because NRR takes into account the mortality of the girls born, not the total number of children born to a woman.
  • • Option
  • • B. NRR (Net Reproduction Rate)
  • • Option C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) - This option is incorrect because GFR is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group, not the total number of children born to an individual woman.
  • • Option
  • • C. GFR (General Fertility Rate) -
  • • Option D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate) - This option is incorrect because GRR specifically refers to the number of girls born to a woman, not the total number of children born.
  • • Option
  • • D. GRR (Gross Reproduction Rate)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Total Fertility Rate (TFR) is the measure that represents the total number of children born to a woman in comparison with other women of the same reproductive age group.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia

options.label: B
options.text: Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs

options.label: D
options.text: It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.correct_answer: D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Decorticate animal is the one without cerebral cortex.
  • • In man, decorticate condition is caused by intracranial hemorrhage, head injury, brain abscess or brain tumor. Decorticate condition is called decorticate rigidity
  • • Decorticate rigidity is the abnormal postural changes that involve rigid extension of the lower limbs and flexion of the upper limbs at elbow joint across the chest. Wrists and fingers are also flexed. Posture may develop on one side or both sides of the body.
  • • Reflexes at the neck level can be elicited
  • • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs. It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.
  • • When the neck is turned to right, there is flexion of the lower and upper limbs on the opposite side. But, on the same side, there is extension of the limbs.
  • • It may be due to the cutting or lesion of direct corticospinal tract. Some fibers of corticospinal tract are known to have inhibitory influence on the extensor muscles.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia : Incorrect as decorticate rigidity typically does not involve the removal of the basal ganglia.
  • • Option A. It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
  • • Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs : Incorrect as this describes a reverse of the decorticate rigidity posturing.
  • • Option B. Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
  • • Option C. Rigidity is pronounced : This statement is somewhat vague but could be considered true in the context of how muscle rigidity is indeed pronounced in decorticate rigidity. However, it does not specifically describe the characteristic posture associated with decorticate rigidity.
  • • Option C. Rigidity is pronounced

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decorticate rigidity is characterized by flexion of the upper limbs and extension of the lower limbs, often occurring in response to severe brain damage above the midbrain level. It is a distinctive postural manifestation of significant central nervous system disruption.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most severe manifestation of CKD? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperkalemia in CKD patients is a critical condition that requires immediate medical attention due to its potential to cause fatal cardiac disturbances. Always prioritize the management of hyperkalemia in CKD patients to prevent cardiac complications.

questions.text: Lignocaine is used in a loading dose for the treatment of arrhythmias. The loading dose of this drug depends upon which of the following factors? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Volume of distribution

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ volume of distribution

questions.text: What will the corrected reticulocyte count if Hb is 5 g/dl and absolute reticulocyte count is 9%? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The corrected reticulocyte count is essential in evaluating the bone marrow response in anemic patients. It is calculated by adjusting the absolute reticulocyte count according to the degree of anemia (using actual and normal hemoglobin values).

questions.text: Which defect is shown below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Homonymous hemianopia is characterized by the loss of the same side of the visual field in both eyes and is typically caused by lesions in the contralateral optic tract, optic radiation, or occipital lobe.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 infection can uniquely mimic erythroblastosis fetalis by causing severe fetal anemia and related complications through its direct impact on erythroid progenitor cells. Awareness of this potential complication is essential, particularly in pregnant women, as the infection can lead to significant fetal outcomes, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

questions.text: A new drug is tested in clinical trials and was found to have a therapeutic index of 20. Which of the following statements best describes the therapeutic index of the drug? (Fmge Jan 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: It represents the extent of absorption of the drug and is calculated from the area under curve of the plasma concentration vs time graph

options.label: B
options.text: It represents distribution of the drug in different tissues and is calculated by dividing the plasma concentration with the amount of drug given

options.label: C
options.text: It represents the duration of action of the drug and is calculated from the half-life of the drug

options.label: D
options.text: It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

questions.correct_answer: D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. It represents margin of safety of a drug and is calculated as a ratio of LD50 to ED50

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The therapeutic index (TI) is a crucial parameter that represents the margin of safety for a drug. It is calculated as the ratio of LD50 to ED50, indicating the range between an effective dose and a potentially lethal dose. A higher TI indicates a safer drug with a wider margin of safety.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypercarbia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The hand movements shown in the image are characteristic of asterixis or flapping tremors, which is a form of negative myoclonus.
  • • Asterixis is most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy but can also be seen in other conditions such as hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Thyrotoxicosis: This condition typically presents with fine tremors rather than the flapping tremors seen in asterixis.
  • • Option A. Thyrotoxicosis:
  • • Option C. Hemiballismus: This condition involves violent, involuntary movements of one side of the body, not the flapping tremors associated with asterixis.
  • • Option C. Hemiballismus:
  • • Option D. Hypoxia: While hypoxia can cause various neurological symptoms, it is not specifically associated with asterixis.
  • • Option D. Hypoxia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asterixis, or flapping tremors, is a form of negative myoclonus often associated with hepatic encephalopathy and hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis). Recognizing these characteristic hand movements can help identify underlying conditions such as hypercarbia. ​

questions.text: Which virus outbreak occurred in Kerala following consumption of date palm sap? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nipah virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of fruits contaminated with bat secretions. Date palm sap, which is a popular drink in the region, can become contaminated with bat secretions containing the Nipah virus when bats feed on the sap. Consumption of this contaminated sap led to the Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ebola virus transmission occurs through contact with contaminated body fluids from infected individuals. It is not associated with the consumption of date palm sap or fruits.
  • • Option
  • • B. Ebola virus
  • • contaminated body fluids
  • • Option C. Litchi Virus Disease, also known as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES), has been reported in West Bengal. It is linked to the consumption of litchis on an empty stomach by children, which can lead to severe hypoglycemia and death due to the generation of methylenecyclopropylglycine (MCPG).
  • • Option
  • • C. Litchi Virus Disease,
  • • empty stomach by children,
  • • severe hypoglycemia and death
  • • Option D. West Nile Fever, transmitted by the Culex pipiens mosquito, has been reported in Kerala.
  • • Option
  • • D. West Nile Fever,
  • • Note - Although a single case of Ebola virus was reported at the Delhi International Airport, it is not related to the Kerala outbreak caused by the consumption of date palm sap.
  • • Note

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nipah virus outbreak in Kerala was linked to the consumption of date palm sap contaminated with bat secretions containing the virus.

questions.text: Common carotid artery pulse is taken at which level? (FMGE JANUARY 2024 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cricoid cartilage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The "magic of C6" is an important anatomical landmark.
  • • The "magic of C6" is an important anatomical landmark.
  • • At the C6 level, there is the c ricopharyngeal junction, the c ricoid c artilage, and the pulsation of the c ommon c arotid artery can be felt.
  • • c
  • • c
  • • c
  • • c
  • • c
  • • The common carotid artery lies just anterior to the carotid tubercle (also known as the Chassaignac tubercle), which is the anterior tubercle of the transverse process of the C6 vertebra. An artery is palpable when it lies close to a firm bony structure, and in this case, the common carotid artery is palpable due to its proximity to the carotid tubercle at the C6 level.
  • • HNF Cadaveric section
  • • HNF Cadaveric section
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Laryngeal prominence: The laryngeal prominence, also known as the Adam's apple, is located at a higher level than the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.
  • • Option B. Laryngeal prominence:
  • • Option C. Suprasternal notch: The suprasternal notch is located inferior to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct level for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.
  • • Option C. Suprasternal notch:
  • • Option D. Angle of mandible: The angle of the mandible is located superior and lateral to the cricoid cartilage and is not the correct landmark for palpating the common carotid artery pulse.
  • • Option D. Angle of mandible:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The common carotid artery pulse is palpated at the level of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level. The carotid tubercle of the C6 vertebra serves as a bony landmark for the pulsation of the common carotid artery.

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of acute onset fever, and pain in the right lumbar region. It is associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given

options.label: D
options.text: Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

questions.correct_answer: D. Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 h; Continue antibiotics for 5 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The management of acute pyelonephritis during pregnancy involves several key steps to ensure effective treatment and prevent complications:
  • • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring. Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy. Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (≥50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration. Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.
  • • Hospitalization: Necessary for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.
  • • Hospitalization:
  • • Urine and Blood Cultures: Essential for identifying the pathogen and tailoring antibiotic therapy.
  • • Urine and Blood Cultures:
  • • Intravenous Crystalloids: Used to maintain adequate urine output (≥50 mL/h) and ensure proper hydration.
  • • Intravenous Crystalloids:
  • • Antibiotics: Initially given intravenously, with the switch to oral antibiotics once the patient is afebrile.
  • • Antibiotics:
  • • The incorrect statement is Option D . The correct management protocol dictates:
  • • Option D
  • • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours , not 72 hours. Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days , not just 5 days.
  • • Discharge Criteria: The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours , not 72 hours.
  • • Discharge Criteria:
  • • 24 hours
  • • Duration of Antibiotics: The recommended course of antibiotics is 7 to 10 days , not just 5 days.
  • • Duration of Antibiotics:
  • • 7 to 10 days
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics: Correct. Hospitalization, urine and blood cultures, and starting antibiotics are all appropriate steps in managing acute pyelonephritis.
  • • Option A. Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures and start on antibiotics:
  • • Option B. Oral antibiotics once afebrile: Correct. Switching to oral antibiotics is appropriate once the patient is afebrile.
  • • Option B.
  • • Oral antibiotics once afebrile:
  • • Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given: Correct. Maintaining a urine output of > 50 mL/h and using intravenous crystalloids are standard practices to manage hydration and ensure adequate renal function.
  • • Option C. Maintain urine output > 50 ml/h; Intravenous crystalloids can be given:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Discharge from the hospital should be considered once the patient is afebrile for 24 hours, and antibiotics should be continued for 7 to 10 days in cases of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 2594, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which among the following will not be seen in this child? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Visible peristalsis from left to right

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bilious vomiting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age. It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS. Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS. A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting. Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria. Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting. The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia). Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria. Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.
  • ➤ CHPS (congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis) is most commonly seen in infants between 2 to 8 weeks of age.
  • ➤ It is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the Pylorus, which results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • ➤ First-born male infants are at the highest risk for developing CHPS.
  • ➤ Projectile, non-bilious vomiting is a common symptom in infants with CHPS.
  • ➤ A palpable olive-shaped mass is usually felt in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium, and visible peristalsis can be observed moving from left to right, followed by projectile vomiting.
  • ➤ Infants with CHPS develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality including hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Loss of hydrochloric acid leads to metabolic alkalosis and hypochloremia due to persistent vomiting.
  • ➤ The kidneys try to compensate for alkalosis by secreting Na+ and HCO3, but the loss of sodium stimulates aldosterone secretion leading to the loss of potassium ions (hypokalemia).
  • ➤ Loss of H+ ions in urine lowers the urinary pH resulting in paradoxical aciduria.
  • ➤ Treatment involves rehydration and correction of metabolic abnormalities before surgery, and the Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for CHPS.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.explanation: Ans. C) Depressed skull fracture

questions.text: What renal function does the formula UV/P represent? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clearance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The formula UV/P is used to calculate the renal clearance of a substance, reflecting the volume of plasma from which the kidneys can completely remove that substance per unit time.

questions.text: A patient fell down riding a bicycle. He started having pain around hip. There was shortening of limb, and the attitude of limb was Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be observed in a patient diagnosed with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leukemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with PNH frequently experience hemolysis, thrombosis, and can develop aplastic anemia. While leukemia can occur as a later complication, it is not a typical presenting feature of PNH.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1213
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1213

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to defect in which of the following cell?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Type 2 pneumocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, is commonly due to insufficient surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes. This deficiency impedes the lungs' ability to expand properly, leading to respiratory distress. Management often includes the administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive care to enhance lung function until the infant's own cells can produce adequate surfactant.

questions.text: Heme is derived from which of the following amino acids? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glycine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Heme is derived from glycine, which is one of the simplest amino acids. Despite its simplicity, glycine is a precursor to several important biological compounds. In the heme biosynthesis pathway, glycine combines with succinyl-CoA to form δ-aminolevulinic acid, which is the first step in the synthesis of heme. Heme is a critical component of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and various cytochromes, playing a vital role in oxygen transport and cellular respiration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved in various metabolic processes, including the synthesis of nucleotides and amino sugars, but it does not contribute directly to heme biosynthesis.
  • • Option A. Glutamine:
  • • Option C. Glutamate: Glutamate is a key neurotransmitter and is involved in the synthesis of glutathione and other amino acids but not directly in heme formation.
  • • Option C. Glutamate:
  • • Option D. Valine: Valine is a branched-chain amino acid important in protein synthesis and energy metabolism but not in the biosynthesis of heme.
  • • Option D. Valine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Products of amino acids -
  • ➤ Products of amino acids -
  • ➤ Tryptophan – Niacin, serotonin, melatonin Tyrosine - Melanin, catecholamine, thyroxin Histidine – Histamine, Carnosine, Anserine Glycine- Creatine, Glutathione, Haem , Porphyrin, Glyoxylate, Choline, Betaine, serine, Sarcosine
  • ➤ Tryptophan – Niacin, serotonin, melatonin
  • ➤ Tyrosine - Melanin, catecholamine, thyroxin
  • ➤ Histidine – Histamine, Carnosine, Anserine
  • ➤ Glycine- Creatine, Glutathione, Haem , Porphyrin, Glyoxylate, Choline, Betaine, serine, Sarcosine
  • ➤ Haem
  • ➤ Glutathione – tripeptide → Glutamate, Cysteine & Glycine
  • ➤ Creatine- made from 3 AA → Arginine, Methionine & Glycine
  • ➤ Serine → Glycine, Selenocysteine, Phosphatidyl serine, Sphingosine (Serine + Palmitoyl CoA) Arginine - NO, Creatine, Urea & Ornithine
  • ➤ Serine → Glycine, Selenocysteine, Phosphatidyl serine, Sphingosine (Serine + Palmitoyl CoA)
  • ➤ Arginine - NO, Creatine, Urea & Ornithine

questions.text: A case of urinary bladder stone with a history of Proteus infection is likely to be? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urinary bladder stones associated with Proteus infection are most likely to be struvite (triple phosphate) stones, formed due to the alkalinizing effect of urease-producing bacteria on the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.
  • • Option A. Halothane:
  • • Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.
  • • Option B. Desflurane:
  • • Option D. Isoflurane : Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.
  • • Option D. Isoflurane

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mode of inheritance shown by the pedigree analysis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An autosomal recessive inheritance pattern is characterized by the presence of affected individuals with unaffected parents, indicating that the parents are carriers and the disease manifests when two recessive alleles are inherited.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) S phase

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • S phase of the cell cycle is considered the most radioresistant. During the S phase, cells are actively duplicating their DNA. The replication machinery during this phase makes the DNA less accessible to radiation-induced damage and the cell has enhanced mechanisms to repair any damage that does occur, thereby making it more resistant to the effects of radiation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. M phase: The mitotic phase where cells are actively dividing. This phase and G2 are often considered more radiosensitive because cells are highly vulnerable to damage during mitosis.
  • • Option B. M phase:
  • • Option C. G1 phase: The first gap phase where cells grow and prepare to synthesize DNA. This phase is relatively more radiosensitive compared to the S phase.
  • • Option C. G1 phase:
  • • Option D. G2 phase: The second gap phase right before mitosis where cells prepare to divide. This phase is typically more radiosensitive, as cells are preparing for mitosis and have less capability for DNA repair compared to the S phase.
  • • Option D. G2 phase:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fulvestrant is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist, also known as a Selective Estrogen Receptor Down-regulator (SERD). Unlike SERMs, fulvestrant has no agonist activity in any tissue. It binds to estrogen receptors and causes their degradation, preventing estrogen receptor dimerization so that ER interaction with DNA is prevented. The ER is thus down-regulated, resulting in complete suppression of estrogen-responsive gene function.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Raloxifene - This is incorrect. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that exhibits tissue-selective effects. It acts as an estrogen receptor agonist in bone (increasing bone formation and preventing osteoporosis) and blood vessels (improving lipid profile), but acts as an antagonist in breast and endometrial tissues. Option B. Tamoxifen - This is incorrect. Tamoxifen is also a SERM with mixed agonist and antagonist effects. It acts as an antagonist in breast tissue (making it useful for breast cancer treatment) but has estrogenic effects on the endometrium, which can increase the risk of endometrial proliferation and cancer. Option D. Clomiphene - This is incorrect. Clomiphene is a SERM that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in the pituitary, which blocks estrogenic feedback inhibition of gonadotropin secretion. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating ovulation. It's used to treat anovulatory infertility.
  • • Option A. Raloxifene - This is incorrect. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that exhibits tissue-selective effects. It acts as an estrogen receptor agonist in bone (increasing bone formation and preventing osteoporosis) and blood vessels (improving lipid profile), but acts as an antagonist in breast and endometrial tissues.
  • • Option A. Raloxifene
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen - This is incorrect. Tamoxifen is also a SERM with mixed agonist and antagonist effects. It acts as an antagonist in breast tissue (making it useful for breast cancer treatment) but has estrogenic effects on the endometrium, which can increase the risk of endometrial proliferation and cancer.
  • • Option B. Tamoxifen
  • • Option D. Clomiphene - This is incorrect. Clomiphene is a SERM that acts as an estrogen receptor antagonist in the pituitary, which blocks estrogenic feedback inhibition of gonadotropin secretion. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating ovulation. It's used to treat anovulatory infertility.
  • • Option D. Clomiphene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fulvestrant is distinct from SERMs (like raloxifene, tamoxifen, and clomiphene) in that it is a pure estrogen receptor antagonist with no agonist activity in any tissue, allowing it to be effective in cases of tamoxifen-resistant breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea. Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea. Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea. Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Sheehan's syndrome:
  • • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Asherman's syndrome:
  • • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Turner mosaic:
  • • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.
  • • Premature ovarian failure:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.
  • • Option A. Turner's mosaic:
  • • Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.
  • • Option C. Sheehan's syndrome:
  • • Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.
  • • Option D. Asherman's syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg375
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg375

questions.text: John, a 55-year-old man, visits his primary care physician due to progressively worsening symptoms of difficulty swallowing and chest pain over the past few weeks. The physician refers John for an esophageal endoscopy to investigate the cause of his symptoms. During the endoscopy, the gastroenterologist observes serpiginous ulcers in John's esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis indicated by these findings?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. CMV esophagitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis is an infection of the esophagus caused by the Cytomegalovirus. It predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or transplant recipients. The characteristic endoscopic finding in CMV esophagitis is the presence of large, linear or serpiginous (snake-like) ulcers, often located in the distal esophagus. These ulcers typically have well-defined edges and are surrounded by relatively normal mucosa, which helps to differentiate them from other types of esophagitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Candida Esophagitis: Candida esophagitis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans. It is common in immunocompromised patients or those on prolonged antibiotics or inhaled steroids. Endoscopic findings typically show white-yellow plaques or patches that can be scraped off, often described as having a "cottage cheese-like" appearance, rather than serpiginous ulcers.
  • • Option B. Candida Esophagitis:
  • • Option C. Herpetic Esophagitis: Herpetic esophagitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV) and can affect both immunocompromised and immunocompetent individuals. It is characterized by odynophagia (painful swallowing) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing). Endoscopically, herpetic esophagitis usually presents with small, well-circumscribed ulcers that resemble "volcano-like" or "punched-out" lesions, which are different from the serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV esophagitis.
  • • Option C. Herpetic Esophagitis:
  • • Option D. Radiation Esophagitis: Radiation esophagitis is a side effect of radiation therapy, particularly for cancers in the chest area, such as lung cancer. It manifests with symptoms like pain, difficulty swallowing, and a sensation of something stuck in the throat. Endoscopic findings may include mucosal redness, swelling, and non-specific ulcerations, but not the distinct serpiginous ulcers typical of CMV esophagitis.
  • • Option D. Radiation Esophagitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serpiginous ulcers in the esophagus observed during endoscopy are characteristic of CMV esophagitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This feature helps differentiate it from other forms of esophagitis such as Candida, herpetic, and radiation-induced esophagitis.

questions.text: The hard palate contains?(NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

options.label: B
options.text: Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, no salivary glands

options.label: C
options.text: Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

options.label: D
options.text: Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, minor salivary glands

questions.correct_answer: A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, minor salivary glands

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hard palate is composed of keratinized epithelium to withstand mechanical stress, a submucosa that provides structural support, and contains minor salivary glands, which are essential for the lubrication and initial digestion of food. This structural composition is crucial for its function in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A sewage worker presented with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and blood in the urine for the past 5 days. Which of the following is the investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The microscopic agglutination test is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in symptomatic individuals, especially those exposed to potentially contaminated water environments. Early diagnosis and treatment are key to preventing severe complications like Weil's disease.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong regarding Weber's syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.correct_answer: D. Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Ipsilateral paralysis of lower face

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weber’s syndrome involves ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral hemiplegia due to midbrain lesions, and does not typically include ipsilateral facial paralysis, which is associated with pontine lesions.

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

questions.text: Under the Urban health care system of India, the following health centre is not included: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) District hospital

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • District hospitals, however, are not a part of the urban healthcare system's primary or secondary level facilities, hence they are not included.
  • • Urban Health care system of India
  • • Urban Health care system of India
  • • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres , which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000. These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres , serve a population of 50,000 . Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh . At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities .
  • • There is a provision for creating urban health and wellness centres , which cater to a population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • • urban health and wellness centres
  • • population of 15,000 to 20,000.
  • • These centres are akin to primary health centres (PHCs) in rural areas. Additionally, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), previously known as Urban Health Centres , serve a population of 50,000 .
  • • Urban Health Centres
  • • 50,000
  • • Urban polyclinics are created for a population of 2.5 to 3 lakh .
  • • Urban polyclinics
  • • population of 2.5 to 3 lakh
  • • At the secondary level, Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC) are established for a population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities .
  • • Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC)
  • • population of 2.5 lakh in non-metro cities and 5 lakh in metro cities

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ District hospitals are not included in the urban healthcare system of India; instead, urban health facilities include Urban Health and Wellness Centres, Urban Primary Health Centres (UPHC), Urban Polyclinics, and Urban Community Health Centres (UCHC).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with painful genital ulcers along with painful inguinal buboes. He had a history of multiple sexual partners. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chancroid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chancroid should be suspected in a patient with painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes), especially in the absence of a history of recurrence and when syphilis and LGV have been ruled out based on the clinical presentation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient with a history of mitral valve replacement on anticoagulation with warfarin is about to undergo hernioplasty for inguinal hernia. What is the target INR prior to surgery? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1.5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Prior to any major surgery, including abdominal surgeries like hernioplasty, it is crucial to manage the patient's anticoagulation status to minimize the risk of excessive bleeding.
  • • For patients on warfarin, the target INR should be brought to less than 1.5 before the surgery.
  • • This can be achieved by stopping warfarin and administering vitamin K if necessary.
  • • If the INR remains above 1.5 on the day of surgery, fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may be administered to rapidly lower the INR. This approach balances the need to prevent excessive bleeding during surgery while managing the risk of thromboembolic complications.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. 0.5-0.8 : This range is too low for general surgical preparation and would indicate a significant reversal of anticoagulation, which is not typically required.
  • • Option A. 0.5-0.8
  • • Option C. 1.5-2 : While this range might be acceptable for some minor procedures, major surgeries generally require an INR of less than 1.5 to ensure safety.
  • • Option C. 1.5-2
  • • Option D. 2-3 : This range is appropriate for therapeutic anticoagulation but is too high for surgical procedures due to the increased risk of bleeding.
  • • Option D. 2-3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ For patients on warfarin undergoing major surgery, the target INR should be less than 1.5 to minimize bleeding risk.

questions.text: A study was undertaken to evaluate the effect of Dietary modification on Serum cholesterol. A group of 100 people were chosen. Their mean cholesterol levels were measured before and after dietary modification. Which statistical test should be applied to test significance? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Paired student’s t-test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The paired student’s t-test is the appropriate statistical test for comparing means of paired quantitative data collected from the same group before and after an intervention.
